name: Naples, Italy
description: Extremely strong tradition in Naples. Fingers down = protection against malocchio (evil eye). Small horn pendants hung in cars and homes. Coral horns especially prized. Part of daily life and serious belief system.

name: Sicily, Italy
description: Particularly powerful tradition in Sicily. Horns worn as necklaces, displayed in homes. Believed to immediately draw evil gaze and blind it. Ancient pre-Christian origins. Both gesture and physical amulets widely used.

name: Calabria, Italy
description: Deep-rooted tradition of horn amulets and gestures. Often worn as jewelry. Horns point down for protection, up for insult. Associated with ancient fertility and animal power beliefs.

name: Rome, Italy
description: Used throughout Lazio region. Gesture made when discussing bad luck or misfortune. Fingers pointing down = warding off evil. Fingers up = accusation of infidelity ('cornuto' = cuckold).

name: Tuscany, Italy
description: Common protective gesture. Used when mentioning death, illness, or bad luck. Less intense than southern Italian practice but still widespread.

name: Sardinia, Italy
description: Ancient tradition with pre-Christian Nuragic roots. Horn amulets found in archaeological sites. Still used for protection against evil eye and general misfortune.

name: Corsica, France
description: Strong Corsican tradition influenced by Italian culture. Horned hand amulets common. Small blessings tradition documented. Protection against bad luck and envy.

name: Malta
description: Mediterranean island tradition. Horn charms worn for protection. Influenced by Italian and ancient Phoenician beliefs. Often combined with eye beads.

name: Ancient Greece
description: Ancient protective gesture documented in classical antiquity. Used against evil spirits and malevolent forces. Belief that horns had divine protective power. Origin of later Mediterranean traditions.

name: Modern Greece
description: Continuation of ancient tradition. Used to ward off evil eye ('mati'). Gesture made when discussing misfortune. Often combined with spitting 'ftou ftou'.

name: Cyprus
description: Strong Mediterranean tradition. Protection against evil eye especially important. Both Greek and Turkish Cypriot communities use similar protective gestures.

name: Crete, Greece
description: Ancient Minoan roots. Archaeological evidence of horn-shaped amulets from Bronze Age. Continuous tradition of protective horn gestures and symbols.

name: Andalusia, Spain
description: Southern Spanish tradition with Mediterranean and Moorish influences. Used against 'mal de ojo' (evil eye). Less widespread than in Italy but still present in traditional communities.

name: Basque Country
description: Ancient pre-Roman tradition. Horns associated with protective animal spirits. Both gesture and amulets used. Part of broader system of protective folk magic.

name: Portugal
description: Used against 'mau-olhado' (evil eye). Less common than in Mediterranean but present in traditional rural communities. Often combined with Catholic protective practices.

name: Buenos Aires, Argentina
description: Brought by Italian immigrants (especially from Naples and Sicily). Still used in Italian-Argentine communities. Protective gesture against 'mal de ojo' and general bad luck.

name: São Paulo, Brazil
description: Italian immigrant tradition, especially strong in Italian neighborhoods. Used by Italian-Brazilian families. Often worn as small gold or coral pendants.

name: New York/New Jersey, USA
description: Strong Italian-American tradition. 'Cornicello' (little horn) pendants worn for luck. Gesture used to ward off evil eye. Featured prominently in Italian-American culture and media.

name: Montreal, Canada
description: Italian immigrant communities maintain tradition. Used in 'Little Italy' neighborhoods. Both gesture and horn amulets still seen, though declining with younger generations.

name: Ancient Rome
description: Ancient Roman protective gesture. Archaeological evidence from Pompeii, Herculaneum. Used alongside fascinus (phallic amulets) as protection. Belief in animal horns' divine protective power dates to pre-Roman Italy.

name: Pompeii/Herculaneum
description: Extensive archaeological evidence of horn symbols and amulets. Carvings, mosaics, and physical amulets preserved by volcanic eruption. Shows central role in Roman protective magic.

name: Leptis Magna, Libya
description: Multiple relief sculptures showing horn gestures. Evidence of spread throughout Roman Empire. North African adoption of Roman protective traditions.

name: Hadrian's Wall, England
description: Several instances of horn amulets and carvings found along wall. Roman soldiers carried protective amulets throughout Empire. Evidence of belief system's geographic spread.

name: Camulodunum (Colchester), England
description: Largest known collection of horn amulets from Roman Britain. Shows importance in Roman military and civilian life. Protection for vulnerable populations (children, soldiers).

name: Ancient Etruria (Tuscany)
description: Pre-Roman Etruscan origins of horn beliefs. Neolithic period evidence of horn symbolism. Belief that animal horns brought fortune and fertility. Foundation for later Roman and Italian traditions.

name: Turkey (Anatolia)
description: Horn-like amulets used alongside evil eye beads. Influenced by ancient Greek, Roman, and Islamic protective traditions. Less emphasis on hand gesture, more on horn-shaped amulets.
